awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Multidisciplinary Physics Research at the University of Memphis
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in Multidisciplinary Physics and Materials Science offers undergraduate students a unique opportunity to engage in cutting edge research in basic and applied physics. The ultimate goal of the scheduled activities is to provide students with a robust platform to successfully launch their careers in all areas of science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). The Multidisciplinary Physics REU Site provides a balance between formal instruction, independent research, and professional development. In this manner, the students are taught the basic skills needed to conduct research, while at the same time becoming aware of the larger scientific community and their contribution within it. Activities are tailored to enhance student research skills along with an emphasis on preparing them for advanced careers in STEM. Activities include a technical writing workshop, special topic lectures by experts, field trips to local industries and research institutions, biweekly networking events, and a student-centered seminar series. Students can choose from a variety of projects that span the multidisciplinary nature of physics and materials science in either computational or experimental areas. The activities and workshops that students engage in address the challenges that students from community colleges and minority institutions face when transitioning to four-year universities and graduate programs in STEM. 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Each participating student will benefit from spending a summer on UofM campus immersed in a research-intensive program in the Physics and Materials Science Department. Under the tutelage and guidance of an experienced faculty researcher and mentor, students conduct research in multidisciplinary areas of physics through synthesis, characterization, modeling, and computation. Students can choose from a variety of research projects from four main themes: Theme 1: Nanomaterials for Energy Applications, Theme 2: Biophysics, Theme 3: Photonics/Plasmonics, and Theme 4: Computational Physics. Students are given the opportunity to continue their research with their appointed faculty mentor after the REU program has finished. Following the orientation (welcome note, laboratory safety training, library training, and campus orientation) and appointment of a mentor, all students receive hands-on training with research-grade instruments such as profilometer, light and electron microscopes, spectroscopes, other materials analysis tools, and computational tools and techniques. Students that successfully complete this research training are well-equipped for STEM careers and graduate programs in the same field or in a related discipline. This REU site is primarily focused on providing access and opportunities to students in the local mid-South area, nearby HBCUs, local community colleges, and is open to first and second year students. A sound strategy of post-program assessment utilizing the Undergraduate Research Student Self-Assessment (URSSA) tool, is implemented and used for and tracking of participants post completion of the training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) grant was awarded to the University of Memphis by the National Science Foundation in 2019. The purpose of this grant was to provide (a) provide robust, mentored research experiences in areas of cutting-edge multidisciplinary physics; (b) provide intense training in the process of the scientific investigation, critical thinking, and ethical conduct of research; (c) provide networking and professional development opportunities; and (d) encourage students to pursue STEM careers. Over the course of the program, 23 undergraduate students and 2 high school students worked within research groups housed in the Department of Physics and Materials Science at the University of Memphis. Nineteen of these students were external to the University of Memphis. Cost savings from online operations during the global COVID-19 pandemic allowed the grant to partially support an additional year of the REU program without additional cost to the National Science Foundation. These students performed research across all areas of physics, including both experimental and theoretical soft and hard condensed matter, observational, and computational astronomy, with 9 faculty mentors and their graduate students involved with guiding the students. The general areas that students were involved with and received training in (both experimentally and computationally) include materials physics, biomaterials, and cosmology.

 

The participants were primarily from institutions/ regions and departments that did not have strong research programs as well as an HBCU institution.  Follow up surveys reflected overall great satisfaction with the program. The duration of the program was considered by some too long and by others too short. Part of the challenge was that the dates overlapped at least one other institution’s semester start/ end dates. This issue was addressed by allowing the student(s) affected to present remotely at the closing ceremony, or, arrive a few days later than other students in that particular cohort. Finally, 4 local students were either partially or fully supported by available UofM funds which allowed the program to benefit a larger number of students than initially funded.

 

The students who completed this program were thoroughly trained in ethics of conducting research, laboratory safety protocols, technical and scientific writing, career preparation for academic and non-academic trajectories, intellectual property and invention disclosures, as well as presenting and preparing for interviews.  To complete the program, all students were required to submit a student-authored research paper to the University of Memphis undergraduate research journal, QuasitUM, which was reviewed internally and the feedback provided to the students served as a great learning opportunity for technical and professional writing at the undergraduate level. Students were provided information related to applying to graduate school, fellowship opportunities, and differences between varying research environments (academic, government laboratories, and industry). External site visits to local industry and research locations including Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO), the UofM planetarium, and ice-cream socials with other regional REU programs were provided during the program, and both academic and industry speakers were brought in to discuss various career pathways. Of the participants in the program, 80 percent have reported to have begun graduate programs or are in the process of applying, with more looking to commence following graduation. Eight five percent of the students have either presented their work at regional conferences, including the Southeastern Section of the American Physical Society annual meeting, are co-authors on conference abstracts and proceedings, and/ or peer-reviewed journal articles.
